bugRzilla 0.0.90001

R bugs

Source: vignettes/bugRzilla.Rmd
bugRzilla.Rmd
library(bugRzilla)

Introduction

Some time ago the R core team requested help with bugs in bugzilla. Some time later on a thank you post they reported bugs closed over time. Which pointed out that we, users, package developer might not be helping enough. This packages tries to lower the barrier to improve R by finding bugs, testing and checking they are reproducible.

To do so this package is to support ease the interaction with bugzilla for a user who wants to:

  • see what happened/what’s happening.

  • submit/validate/comment on existing issues.

To do so it uses the Bugzilla API1 and sometimes the accessible xml files.

The package

We can check if there has been an update recently with:

check_last_audit()
#> [1] "2021-02-12 16:36:11 UTC"

Getting data

Issues

To get information about which issues exists you can call get_bug() :

bugs <- get_bug(1:100)
head(bugs)
#>   target_milestone is_confirmed severity classification
#> 1              ---         TRUE   normal   Unclassified
#> 2              ---         TRUE   normal   Unclassified
#> 3              ---         TRUE   normal   Unclassified
#> 4              ---         TRUE   normal   Unclassified
#> 5              ---         TRUE   normal   Unclassified
#> 6              ---         TRUE   normal   Unclassified
#>                              cc_detail is_creator_accessible         op_sys

#> 3                                   NA                  TRUE        Solaris

#> 6      FIXED       NA       R     old   FALSE manish0731582008
plot(bugs$id, bugs$creation_time, 
     main = "Bug ID vs creation time", xlab = "ID", 
     ylab = "Creation Time")

We can see that the first issue is created in 2010 while the next issues are from before 2000. This is because the first issues is a test and next issues were ported from jitterbug.

We can also see that there are some blank spaces between bugs ids. Perhaps some reports where deleted or simply they didn’t got filled.

There’s information about who created, about what, version, resolution, priority…

Comments

We can now collect information about comments on issues:

get_comment(issue = 1)
#>   is_private count                time       creator tags    id bug_id
#> 1      FALSE     0 2010-02-15 18:29:54         admin   NA     1      1
#> 2      FALSE     1 2010-02-15 18:33:25         admin   NA     2      1
#> 3      FALSE     2 2010-02-16 17:42:59         admin   NA     3      1
#> 4      FALSE     3 2010-03-09 18:14:23 simon.urbanek   NA 83214      1
#> 5      FALSE     4 2010-03-10 16:54:39         admin   NA 83218      1
#>   is_markdown attachment_id       creation_time
#> 1       FALSE            NA 2010-02-15 18:29:54
#> 2       FALSE            NA 2010-02-15 18:33:25
#> 3       FALSE             1 2010-02-16 17:42:59
#> 4       FALSE            NA 2010-03-09 18:14:23
#> 5       FALSE            NA 2010-03-10 16:54:39
#>                                                                     text
#> 1                          Bug report description.\n\nAnother paragraph.
#> 2                                                   Another response ...
#> 3 Created attachment 1\ntest attachment ...\n\nAttaching a test file ...
#> 4                      Additional comment ... test, as you may guess ...
#> 5                                         Msrking the test bug as fixed.

Or if we know the id of the comment, of just that comment:

get_comment(comment = 1)
#>   bug_id       creation_time is_markdown
#> 1      1 2010-02-15 18:29:54       FALSE
#>                                            text attachment_id is_private count
#> 1 Bug report description.\n\nAnother paragraph.            NA      FALSE     0
#>                  time creator tags id
#> 1 2010-02-15 18:29:54   admin   NA  1

Attachments

If you look carefully you’ll see that the third comment on the first issue has an attachment id. We can also explore what it is:

get_attachment(issue = 1)
#>   id creator is_obsolete    last_change_time
#> 1  1   admin       FALSE 2010-02-16 17:43:29
#>                                                                                                                                                                                   data
#> 1 I2luY2x1ZGUgPFJpbnRlcm5hbHMuaD4KClNFWFAgbXlFdmFsKFNFWFAgRk4sIFNFWFAgZmlyc3RfYXJnKSB7CiAgcmV0dXJuIGV2YWwoTENPTlMoRk4sIENPTlMoZmlyc3RfYXJnLCBSX05pbFZhbHVlKSksIFJfR2xvYmFsRW52KTsKfQo=
#>   size is_private             summary content_type       creation_time
#> 1  134      FALSE test attachment ...   text/plain 2010-02-16 17:42:59
#>   file_name bug_id is_patch flags
#> 1      ed.c      1    FALSE    NA
# Similar to get_comment we can also do
# get_attachment(attachment = 1)

If you want all the information of an issue including attachments you have get_issue() :

issue1 <- get_issue(1)
issue1[, 1:5]
#>   attachid commentid comment_count           who            bug_when
#> 2       NA         1             0         admin 2010-02-15 18:29:54
#> 3       NA         2             1         admin 2010-02-15 18:33:25
#> 1        1         3             2         admin 2010-02-16 17:42:59
#> 4       NA     83214             3 simon.urbanek 2010-03-09 18:14:23
#> 5       NA     83218             4         admin 2010-03-10 16:54:39

This function doesn’t use the API and is slower.

History

If you want to know what changed you can with get_history() :

get_history(issue = 1)
#>                  when                         who
#> 1 2010-02-16 17:43:29          admin@urbanek.info
#> 2 2010-03-09 18:14:23 simon.urbanek@r-project.org
#> 3 2010-03-10 16:54:39          admin@urbanek.info
#> 4 2014-04-19 11:23:06  shanghaihuinanzhen@163.com
#> 5 2014-04-19 11:25:51  shanghaihuinanzhen@163.com
#> 6 2014-07-08 07:00:35      kaushjaiswal@gmail.com
#> 7 2015-12-14 13:44:54  maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch
#> 8 2018-01-16 16:21:14  maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch
#>                                                         changes issue
#> 1 attachments.mimetype, application/octet-stream, text/plain, 1     1
#> 2                             simon.urbanek@r-project.org, cc,      1
#> 3                    RESOLVED, status, NEW, resolution, , FIXED     1
#> 4                                           15763, , depends_on     1
#> 5                                           15764, , depends_on     1
#> 6                                           15862, , depends_on     1
#> 7                                      status, RESOLVED, CLOSED     1
#> 8                                    R 2.y.z, version, R 2.11.0     1

Authentication

Most queries do not require authentication but some do. To set up an authentication you’ll need a user (You have to ask for an account to bug-report-request@r-project.org), and then create an API key.

create_api_key()

This will ask you to save your API key to .Renviron. To check that the api key is working (after resetting the R session) you have:

check_key()

  1. The full documentation of the API is here.↩︎
